div.head: Summary
div.p: Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease, or, as it is alternatively titled, Eight Verses Praising the Glorious Goddess Mahākālī, is a short praise to the goddess Mahākālī in which she is portrayed as a source of protection from disease. The text is included in the Compendium of Dhāraṇīs section of the Degé Kangyur as well as in the Tantra section of the Degé Tengyur, and it was composed by the brahmin Vararuci.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This text was translated by Catherine Dalton and edited by the 84000 editorial team.
The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.

Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease, or, as it is alternatively titled, Eight Verses Praising the Glorious Goddess Mahākālī, is a short praise to the wrathful goddess Mahākālī composed by the brahmin Vararuci.

Not much is known about the work’s author, the brahmin Vararuci, but in addition to this praise to Mahākālī, a series of works related to Mahākāla included in the Tengyur—two sādhanas, an empowerment rite, and a praise—are also attributed to him. The four Mahākāla-related works attributed to Vararuci are two Mahākāla-sādhanas (Toh 1761 and Toh 3386) , the Mahākālābhiṣeka-vidhi (Toh 1763), and a Mahākāla-stotra (Toh 1774). One Vararuci (or, more probably, several Vararucis) also authored a number of scientific and astrological texts composed in Sanskrit, but without further evidence it seems unlikely that those texts were authored by the same Vararuci who authored the several Buddhist works related to Mahākāla and Mahākālī that survive in Tibetan translation.

This praise does not appear to survive in Sanskrit or to have been translated into Chinese. The text is included in the Compendium of Dhāraṇīs (gzungs ’dus) section of the Degé Kangyur and other Tshalpa-lineage Kangyurs that include a separate dhāraṇī section. Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease is one of only fifteen texts in the Compendium of Dhāraṇīs section of the Degé Kangyur (and the other Kangyurs that include such a section) that, unlike the other 235 works in the Compendium, do not also appear in duplicate in other sections of the Kangyur. In Tshalpa-lineage Kangyurs that lack a section so named, the text is found in the Tantra section, but only in the equivalent but unnamed dhāraṇī collection comprising part of the Tantra section. It is not found in any Kangyurs belonging to the Thempangma grouping, such as the Stok Palace Kangyur, nor do we find it in the Dunhuang collections. Since this text is recognized as having had a human author, the brahmin Vararuci, it is also included in all four recensions of the Tengyur. It seems likely that the work’s inclusion in some Kangyurs, despite clearly being an authored text, may be related to its being part of the Compendium of Dhāraṇīs, which seems to have been compiled on the basis of an earlier collection or collections of dhāraṇīs and associated ritual texts. The opening lines of the table of contents (dkar chag) of an independent dhāraṇī collection printed in Beijing in 1731, found in the Library of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences in Budapest and transcribed by Orosz, identify the source of all such dhāraṇī collections as the extracanonical collection edited by Tāranātha (Orosz 2010, pp. 67 and 100). This mention is also noted by Hidas 2021, p. 7, n. 56). These collections, known in Sanskrit as dhāraṇī­saṃgrahas, appear in South Asia and Tibet—including at Dunhuang and as extracanonical Tibetan dhāraṇī collections—and often include praises as well as dhāraṇīs and dhāraṇī-sūtras. See J. Dalton 2016 and J. Dalton and van Schaik 2006 on the dhāraṇī­saṃgraha collections preserved at Dunhuang, which contain praises and prayers as well as dhāraṇīs. See Hidas 2021 for the catalogs of eighteen dhāraṇī­saṃgraha collections surviving in Sanskrit, many of which also contain praises. As mentioned above, the present work has been preserved under two titles: the recension included in the Kangyurs is titled Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease, while that in the Tengyurs is titled Eight Verses Praising the Glorious Goddess Mahākālī. While these reflect the titles given at the incipit (and thus also in the catalogs) of the Kangyur and Tengyur recensions, the author’s colophons of both recensions show how they may have come to be known under these two different titles. The author’s colophon of the Tengyur recension reprises the title as Eight Verses Praising the Glorious Goddess Mahākālī, the Lady Who Rules All Disease, while the author’s colophon of the Kangyur recension gives it as Eight Verses Praising Mahākālī, the Lady Who Rules All Diseases.

Neither the Kangyur nor the Tengyur recension of this praise includes a translator’s colophon, so we do not know who translated it, but the work is listed in the Denkarma imperial catalog (under the title found in its Kangyur recensions), so we know that it was translated by the early ninth century.

This English translation was completed on the basis of both the Degé Kangyur and Tengyur recensions (Toh 1090This text, Toh 1090, and all those contained in this same volume (gzungs ’dus, waM), are listed as being located in volume 101 of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by the 84000 Reading Room—list this work as being located in volume 102. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the gzungs ’dus section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalog, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Tōhoku catalog placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the Vimalaprabhā­nāmakālacakra­tantraṭīkā (dus ’khor ’grel bshad dri med ’od, Toh 845), before the present volume, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come right at the end of the Degé Kangyur as volume 102; indeed its fifth and final chapter is often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur dkar chag (catalog). Please note this discrepancy when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation. and Toh 1777, respectively) with additional reference to the notes from the Comparative Editions (dpe bsdur ma) of the Kangyur and Tengyur.

div.head: The Translation
Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease
Eight Verses Praising the Glorious Goddess Mahākālī

lg.l: Homage to Glorious Vajrapāṇi. This verse of homage is found only in the Tengyur recension of the text (Toh 1777). It is absent in the Kangyur recension (Toh 1090).

The Tengyur recension of the text (Toh 1777) contains the homage “Homage to Glorious Vajrapāṇi,” which is absent in the Kangyur recension (Toh 1090). O Devī, you wander in this world, naked, riding a donkey—
O Devī, you wander in this world, naked, riding a donkey—
Anointed with sesame oil, your hair a single plait, and with lead earrings, you are seductive and fully adorned,
While iron shackles grace your feet as anklets.

We know your We have emended lha mo khyod nyid kyis to lha mo khyod nyid kyi. nature is beautiful, and yet Following Toh 1090: kyi. Toh 1777: kyis.—who can know the matter of your great ocean of activity for others? |1|
In saṃsāra, at the time of destruction, when from human bodies Following Toh 1777: mi lus. Toh 1090: mi rus (“human bones”). blood and fat ooze forth, and smoke rises,
O Devī, in a single instant you will toss all beings into your terrifying, fanged mouth.

O Kālī, you who hold a human skull—as the domain of yogic practice, Following Toh 1090: rnal ’byor grub pa’i spyod yul can. Toh 1777: rnal ’byor grub pa’i rnal ’byor can. you take delight in cremation grounds,

And the terrifying ringing of your bell subdues the wicked ones Following Toh 1090: g.yo can. Toh 1777: g.yo byed (“what moves”). and dispels and quells Following Toh 1090: ’jigs sel zhi la. In support of this are the Peking and Narthang recensions of Toh 1777: ’jigs pa gsal zhing zhi la. Degé recension of Toh 1777: ’jigs pa bsal zhing (“clear fears and”). all ills and mortal perils. Following Toh 1090: nad dang ’chi ba. Toh 1777: nad chen ’chi ba (“the great illness that is death”). |2|
Adorned with a crown of warriors’ heads, you bear a garland of heads severed on the battlefield.

You dance with your supple arms opened wide, wearing a nāga lord Here “nāga lord” could also be plural. In some manifestations of Śrīdevī her belt consists of several snakes. as a belt across your broad hips.
Intoxicated by the liquor of blood, in your hands you brandish a spear and sword.
Your eyes bloodshot, you are seen by the host of bhūtas who wander cremation grounds at night. |3|

You wear a great Following Toh 1777: chen po. Toh 1090: sar pas (“fresh”). torn Following Toh 1777: dral. Toh 1777: dril (“wrapped”). hide and a half-open shawl, bound with a belt of braided straw. The translation of this sentence follows Toh 1777. An alternative translation, based on Toh 1090, would be as follows: “You are wrapped in a fresh hide, and a wide garment is your shawl—half-open and bound with a belt of braided straw.”
With your moon-like face adorned with strings of fresh human entrails, you ring Following Toh 1777: ’khrol. Toh 1090: ’dril (“wield”). a bell at your cheek.

Your body freshly oiled and painted in patches with drops of blood, fat, and the like, Following Toh 1777: khrag dang zhag la sogs pa’i thig les. Toh 1090: khrag dang zhag mang ’dzag pa’i thig les (“many drops of blood and fat that have dropped down”).
You tear at human flesh Following Toh 1777: mi yi sha. Toh 1090: mi ro’i sha (“human corpse flesh”). with your glistening teeth. O Kāpālikā, protect me! |4|
Fiercest among fierce ladies, terrifying, with human flesh in your mouth—the first time they saw you,
Even the mātṛkās were frightened and terrified as you flew into a rage, your bloodshot eyes flickering about‍—I bow to you!
Beautiful Kālī, your black body is so overwhelming that even Śakra and the rest are compelled
To praise you daily, and even Yama himself will always bow trembling before you. |5|

You who bring an end Following Toh 1777: mjug brtul ba. Toh 1090: mjug brtul bas (“because you bring to an end”). to humans and all living beings, In Toh 1090, the first line in this verse has nineteen syllables, whereas the other three lines in the verse only have seventeen syllables. However, in Toh 1777 all four lines have nineteen syllables, suggesting that Toh 1090 may have lost two syllables in the last three verse lines over the course of the text’s transmission.

On one side, by your ear, is an uraga, whose thousand-headed hood is spread and adorns you. Following Toh 1090. Toh 1777: rna ba ya gcig la/ brang gis ’gro ba ’go bo’i gdengs ka stong dang ldan pa rgyab nas rgyan du byas nas gnas, yet reading ’go bo’i as mgo bo’i (following Toh 1090) (“At one ear is an uraga whose thousand-headed hood adorns you from behind”).
At the other ear, you keep a supreme lion, as you trample the entire Following Toh 1777: ma lus. Toh 1090 omits this. ocean-encircled earth.

The sun that crosses the sky, brilliant with a thousand rays, rests directly at your navel. Following Toh 1777: khyod kyi lte ba’i thad ka’i phyogs su gzhags. Toh 1090: khyod kyis lte ba’i phyogs so bzhag (“you have placed at the position of your navel”). |6|

You are the fire that blazes forth from the expanse of the ocean, “Expanse of the ocean” translates the Tibetan rgya mtsho’i klong, which in turn is attested as a translation of the Sanskrit vaḍabāmukha. Vaḍabāmukha, which means “the mare’s mouth,” is the name for a mythological underwater cavity at the bottom of the sea that contains a fire known as vaḍabāgni (“the mare’s fire”). At some point this fire will erupt and consume the entire world. Some texts, such as The Sovereign Ritual of Amoghapāśa (Amoghapāśakalparāja, Toh 686, 2.128), personify "the mare's mouth" as the deity Vaḍabāmukha, who is sometimes identified with Śiva, possibly in his role as the final destroyer of the universe.
Able to dry up the whole of the sea.

Because all women are pacified, Following 1090: zhi mdzad phyir. 1777: zhi bya’i phyir (“in order to pacify”). This line is likely a reference to Śiva’s lying supine on the battlefield in order to calm Kālī to prevent her from destroying the world.

You are present Following 1090: bzhugs. 1777: bzhag (“placed”). as half of Mahādeva’s body. Our translation of this line is tentative. This could be a reference to Mahākālī as the female part of the half-male, half-female form of Śiva called Ardhanārīśvara (“Lord Who Is Half Female”). |7|
Durgā, Gaurī, Mahākālī,
To whom gods and asuras pay homage,
You who know all that threatens human life—
Render it harmless!
Yama’s Queen, Mother of Māra,

Sovereign Goddess of the Desire Realm‍—I praise you! Following Toh 1777: ’dod khams dbang phyug ma la bstod. Toh 1090: ’dod pa’i khams kyi dbang phyug ma. Toh 1777 includes these two final lines as part of the praise, whereas in Toh 1090 these same two lines—although matching the meter of the preceding lines—instead seem to form part of the text’s colophon. |8|

div.trailer: This concludes “Praising the Lady Who Rules Disease,” composed by the brahmin Vararuci.

gloss.term: Sovereign Goddess of the Desire Realm

A common epithet of Indra, the lord of the gods, who dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu: one who has performed a hundred sacrifices (Tib. brgya byin). The highest Vedic sacrifice was the horse sacrifice, and there is a tradition that he became the lord of the gods through performing a hundred of them.
A goddess; an epithet of Śiva’s consort Pārvatī.
